skill.name: cosmic-database
skill.description: Access COSMIC cancer mutation database. Query somatic mutations, Cancer Gene Census, mutational signatures, gene fusions, for cancer research and precision oncology. Requires authentication.
skill.summary: Access the COSMIC cancer genomics database for mutation data, gene lists, and signatures.
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: All 99 static findings are false positives. The analyzer misidentified markdown code fences as shell backticks, documentation URLs as network indicators, and fabricated cryptographic patterns. This is a legitimate Sanger Institute bioinformatics tool for accessing cancer mutation data.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution (69 locations in SKILL.md, references/cosmic_data_reference.md)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Markdown documentation files use triple backticks for code block syntax highlighting. Examples at SKILL.md:35-37 show ```bash code fences for installation instructions, and SKILL.md:42-86 contain ```python blocks for download examples. Line 59-70 shows bash command examples. These are documentation code examples, not shell execution code. No subprocess, os.system, or shell=True calls exist in any Python files.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: network: Hardcoded URL (15 locations across all files)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: All URLs point to the official Sanger Institute COSMIC website (cancer.sanger.ac.uk). Specific examples: SKILL.md:31 registration URL, SKILL.md:325-327 documentation links, references/cosmic_data_reference.md:7 website URL. These are legitimate academic database endpoints. Network requests in download_cosmic.py:57 use HTTPS with proper authentication to download public cancer genomics data from an authorized source.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: network: Python HTTP libraries (6 locations in scripts/download_cosmic.py:66,93,120,123)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: requests.get() calls in download_cosmic.py are used to download authorized cancer genomics data from COSMIC. Lines 66-69 get download URL, line 93 streams file download, lines 120-123 handle timeout and exceptions. This is legitimate data access functionality for a bioinformatics tool, not suspicious network activity.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: network: Fetch API call (1 location in SKILL.md:240)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Line 240 shows pysam.VariantFile('CosmicCodingMuts.vcf.gz') for reading local VCF files, not a network fetch. This is local file access using the pysam library for variant file processing.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: filesystem: Python file write/append (1 location in scripts/download_cosmic.py:103)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: open(output_filename, 'wb') at line 103 writes downloaded cancer data to disk as part of the expected download workflow. The output_filename is derived from the filepath parameter, not user input. No path traversal risk. This is standard behavior for a data download utility.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: blocker: Weak cryptographic algorithm (14 HIGH severity locations)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: No cryptographic code exists in this repository. The static analyzer appears to have fabricated these findings or misidentified text patterns in documentation. The script uses standard HTTP Basic Auth over HTTPS for API authentication, which is appropriate for Sanger Institute COSMIC API access. No MD5, SHA1, DES, or other weak cryptographic functions are used.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: blocker: System reconnaissance (3 LOW severity locations)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: These references do not exist in the files. The static analyzer likely generated false positives. No reconnaissance, system information gathering, or network scanning code exists. Print statements at download_cosmic.py:65,92,100 are diagnostic output for download progress.

content.value_statement: Cancer researchers need comprehensive mutation data for studies. This skill provides programmatic access to the COSMIC database containing millions of somatic mutations, curated cancer gene lists, and mutational signatures.
actual_capabilities: Download mutation data from COSMIC database using authenticated access
Query Cancer Gene Census for curated cancer gene lists
Retrieve mutational signature profiles for signature analysis
Access structural variants, gene fusions, and copy number alterations
Download resistance mutations with clinical annotations
Work with GRCh37 and GRCh38 genome assemblies
limitations: Requires COSMIC account registration at Sanger Institute
Downloads can be several gigabytes in size

use_cases.title: Analyze mutation data
use_cases.description: Download and analyze somatic mutations for cancer gene studies.

use_cases.title: Build pipelines
use_cases.description: Integrate COSMIC data into bioinformatics analysis workflows.

use_cases.title: Research drug resistance
use_cases.description: Access resistance mutation data for precision medicine research.

prompt_templates.title: Download mutations
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to download the Cancer Gene Census from COSMIC using the download_cosmic.py script. What filepath should I use?

prompt_templates.title: Query by gene
prompt_templates.prompt: What file contains TP53 mutations in COSMIC and how do I filter the downloaded data for a specific gene?

prompt_templates.title: Mutational signatures
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I download and work with COSMIC mutational signatures? What file paths should I use for SBS signatures?

prompt_templates.title: Integrate with VCF
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to read a downloaded CosmicCodingMuts.vcf.gz file using pysam and extract records for chromosome 17.

output_examples.input: Download the Cancer Gene Census from COSMIC
output: âœ“ Contains ~700+ curated cancer genes with roles (oncogene, TSG, fusion)
âœ“ Downloaded file can be read with pandas.read_csv()

best_practices: Use GRCh38 assembly for new projects and specify genome_assembly='GRCh38' in function calls
Use 'latest' in file paths to always get the most recent COSMIC release
Store credentials securely and never hardcode passwords in scripts
anti_patterns: Using GRCh37 for new projects when GRCh38 is the current standard
Downloading entire database when specific subsets meet your needs
Skipping authentication verification before attempting downloads

faq.question: Is COSMIC access free?
faq.answer: Academic users get free access with registration. Commercial users need a QIAGEN license.

faq.question: What genome assembly should I use?
faq.answer: Use GRCh38 for new projects. GRCh37 is available for legacy pipeline compatibility.

faq.question: How large are COSMIC files?
faq.answer: Mutation files can be several gigabytes. The script shows download progress for large files.

faq.question: What file formats are available?
faq.answer: TSV, CSV, and VCF formats. TSV/CSV use gzip compression. VCF files are standard for variant data.

faq.question: How often is COSMIC updated?
faq.answer: COSMIC is updated quarterly. Use 'latest' in file paths for the most recent version.

faq.question: Can I use this with other tools?
faq.answer: Yes, COSMIC data integrates with VEP, pysam, pandas, and standard bioinformatics pipelines.
